citation.article-title: Streptococcus gallinarum sp. nov. and Streptococcus oralis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Streptococcus ferus nom. rev.
Streptococcus ferus (fear's. L. adj. ferrous wild, referring to the wild rats from which the organism was isolated)
Cells are gram-positive cocci 0.5 μm in diameter that occur in pairs and chains.
Mannitol and sorbitol are fermented; raffinose is not.
An adhesive glucan is produced from sucrose.
This species is intolerant of 45°C or 6.5% NaCl.
Ammonia is not produced from arginine.
Colonies on agar containing sucrose are about 1 mm in diameter, raised, and somewhat adherent, with no liquid on or around the colony.
The final pH in 1% glucose broth is 4.2 to 4.5.
The DNA base content is 43 to 45 mol% G+C (9).
The type strain is strain 8S1 (= ATCC 33477).
Additional comments. S. ferus was isolated in Florida from the mouths of wild rats that ate sugarcane and from rats living in a landfill dump in Hartford, Conn.
Strains from the two locales were homologous as determined by DNA hybridization.

Strains of S. ferus react with Bratthall antiserum c, although they are not related (as determined by DNA homology) to S. mutans. S . ferus strains do not grow on agar containing bacitracin (0.2 U/ml).
The cells produce and catabolize intracellular polysaccharide. S. ferous has not been isolated from humans.
Despite their many similarities, the five mutans streptococcal species can be readily identified by biochemical or serological differences.

It is interesting that some authors, although expressing reservations about the taxonomic separation of S. mutans, nevertheless point out the biochemical, serological, and genetic heterogeneity of S . mutans and remark on the good correlation among serotypes, biotypes, and genotypes.
That such clearly separable and genetically different organisms should all be called S. mutans seems unwarranted in light of modern taxonomic objectives.
